item.title: Inscrições prorrogadas
item.description:
As inscrições para a Latinoware 2011 foram prorrogadas até o dia 13 de outubro. Após essa data, só serão aceitas inscrições no dia do evento, também com o valor de R$ 100,00.

Inscreva-se já em: http://lapsi.latinoware.org
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: Versão 11.10 do Ubuntu será a utilizada nos laboratórios da Latinoware
item.description:
A organização da Latinoware 2011 avisa a todos os palestrantes e responsáveis pelos minicursos que a base da matriz dos computadores dos laboratórios do evento será na versão 11.10 do Ubuntu (que será lançado no fim deste mês), na arquitetura de 32 bits.
     
Até a próxima quarta-feira (12), tudo aquilo que for solicitado (pelo e-mail secretaria@latinoware.org) e que esteja disponível em repositórios oficiais (ou indicado pelos próprios palestrantes) será instalado, porém não haverá compilação ou personalização de softwares específicos. Após esta data o palestrante ficará responsável por realizar a instalação e configuração dos softwares necessários para realização do seu minicurso.
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: Gestão Pública com Software Público e Livre - Por onde eu começo?
item.description:
Neste ano a equipe do Portal Software Público Brasileiro (e Internacional) preparou um verdadeiro roteiro para aqueles que trabalham com a administração pública. São palestras abrangentes e de formação, ao alcance de todos aqueles que trabalham com gestão pública e querem aumentar a transparência de seus processos e a interação com seus cidadãos. Aqueles que ouviram falar que é possível fazer tudo isso com software livres mas não sabem como começar!
    
No primeiro dia da Latinoware (19), no Espaço Paraguai, a primeira palestra irá explicar o conceito de Software Público e mostrar como ele pode ser o agente de mudanças no processo de desenvolvimento ágil de softwares, criando um ecossistema que respeita e valoriza talentos e movimenta economias locais. Na sequência, será apresentado um Guia Prático para a adoção de softwares públicos, com enfoque especial na gestão municipal.
   

read more
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: Latinoware divulga programação preliminar de palestras e minicursos
item.description:
Já está no ar uma lista preliminar de palestras e minicursos que serão oferecidos durante a Latinoware 2011. Ao todo, mais de 80 palestrantes de países como Argentina, Bélgica, Chile, Colômbia, Alemanha, Dinamarca, Espanha, França, Itália, Letônia, México, Peru, Paraguai e Estados Unidos já confirmaram a presença no evento.

Palestras
     
Minicursos
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: La senda KDE en el Latinoware 2011
item.description:
The Linux operating system currently relies upon many graphic interfacing options, but KDE might be the option with the longest history among all the interfaces that have been a part of the 20 years of Linux and, before it, Unix. Who still remembers the CDE interface?
  
Sandro Andrade, responsible for the KDE trail at Latinoware, remembers, and he also recalls other graphic interfaces like that of MSX architecture, which was rather popular in Brazil and other countries during the 80s. History and a vision of the future are part of both the KDE story and that of Sandro’s life.
  

1. Sandro, you are a guy that was born plugged in. From MSX to KDE, it seems like information technology diverged and converged many times, and proceeds in a cyclical movement, in terms of it being accessible to everybody. MSX was a computer for “the rest of us”, the non-nerds. What about KDE?
   

read more
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: Canonical and Free Software Business Models
item.description:
According to Maurício Pretto, channels manager at Canonical, software should always be freely available for all users, whether they pay or not. Having this as their philosophical base, Canonical explores business models, from desktops computers to computing clouds. In this interview with the Latinoware team, Maurício told us more about the different ways in which the business profits from free software, the business' initiatives in Cloud Computing, and their principal markets within Brazil.
   
  
1. Maurício, unlike other distributions where there is a certain separation between what belongs to the community, and what belongs to the business, (Redhat and Fedora, SuSE and OpenSuSE), Canonical sells their services using Ubuntu itself, without its own "Ubuntu-based" distribution. Why is that?
    

read more
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: Zabbix Power Savings
item.description:
People are used to see the open source software Zabbix being used more and more as the standard for network operation centers displays, statistics and alerts. What very few know is that Zabbix can go beyond computers and networks monitoring. Actually, with some creativity you could even use Zabbix to monitor all of your electric appliances and save energy at the same time. Learn more about Zabbix in this interview given by Alexei Vladisevs, the Zabbix creator, to our team.
     

 

read more
item.dc:creator: latino2011

item.title: IV KDE Brazil Forum to Take Place During Latinoware
item.description:
Latinoware 2011 will be the home of the Fourth Annual KDE Brazil Forum – Latin American Edition, offering talks and activities that go from agile development to mobile device programing, as well as proposals for community involvement and contributions. Consult the full agenda:

 

Talks
       

1 - 15 Years of KDE: What have we constructed? Where are we going?- Aracele Torres 
       
Aracele Torres is a member of the KDE community for translation and promotion of the software. She is a historian who graduated from the UFPI, and currently is doing her Master´s in the social history of science through the USP, in research on free software, and the GNU project.
    

read more

item.title: Latinoware will have fourth edition of IWEEE: free technologies promoting health
item.description:
The first time Medical, GNUHealth today, was introduced in Brazil was in Latinoware 2009. At the time the software was highlighted for having been chosen as project of the month on SourceForge. Months later, the first IWEEE was organized in the Canary Islands, where GNUHealth and other technological free software solutions were presented. In 2010, we had the second IWEEE in Latinoware, where even at the risk of speaking on a specific subject, in addition to the small audience, we had a major stand out that, among other things, led to the third edition of IWEEE at Med@Tel, the leading global event in Telemedicine.
      
1. Luis, please tell us why everyone (and not only professional health area) should be interested in free health technologies.
      

read more
item.dc:creator: latino2011
